details: The P3 atomic structure has been fitted into improved cryo-EM reconstructions for three types of PRD1 particles: the wild-type virion, a packaging mutant without DNA, and a P3-shell lacking the membrane and the vertices. Establishing the absolute EM scale was crucial for an accurate match. The resulting “quasi-atomic” models of the capsid define the residues involved in the major P3 interactions, within the quasi-equivalent interfaces and with the membrane, and show how these are altered upon DNA packaging.

globalExternalReferences.description: A group of DNA containing viruses which infect mammals and are capable of causing respiratory disease, including one form of the common cold.
globalExternalReferences.label: Adenoviridae

globalExternalReferences.description: The protein coat that surrounds the infective nucleic acid in some virus particles where the subunits (capsomeres) are arranged to form an icosahedron with T=25 symmetry. The T=25 capsid is composed of 12 pentameric and 240 hexameric capsomeres.
globalExternalReferences.label: T=25 icosahedral viral capsid

globalExternalReferences.description: A non-taxonomic grouping of viruses that infect and lyse certain bacteria and archaea.
globalExternalReferences.label: Bacteriophage

globalExternalReferences.description: A non-taxonomic grouping of viruses that infect and lyse certain bacteria and archaea.
globalExternalReferences.label: Bacteriophage

name: Combined EM/X-ray imaging yields a quasi-atomic model of the adenovirus-related bacteriophage PRD1 and shows key capsid and membrane interactions

biologicalAnnotation.description: Homotrimeric molecule of 43.1 kDa per monomer which accounts for 75% of the virion protein

externalReferences.description: The outer protective shell of a virus. The structure of the shell is icosahedral with either helical or complex symmetry. Capsid proteins surround and protect the viral nucleic acid core.
externalReferences.label: Capsid Protein

externalReferences.description: The formation of a protein homotrimer, a macromolecular structure consisting of three noncovalently associated identical subunits.
externalReferences.label: protein homotrimerization

biologicalAnnotation.name: P3 trimer

software.name: Segger (UCSF Chimera)
software.processingDetails:
Micrographs were digitized in a Zeiss-SCAI scanner using a step size of 7 or 14 μm and interpolated to 14 μm. This gives a nominal pixel size in the sample of 3.68 Å for micrographs recorded at 36,000× or 2.8 Å for those recorded at 50,000×. Individual micrographs (5 for the P3-shell, 29 for sus1, and 12 for the wt virion) were selected that showed an adequate ice thickness and particle distribution and were free of drift and astigmatism. The contrast transfer function (CTF) parameters of each micrograph were determined from its rotationally averaged power spectrum, obtained by patch averaging. Particle selection was either done manually in SPIDER or automatically in ETHAN. Centering, masking, and ramping were performed using SPIDER. Initial particle orientations for CTF-multiplied images were obtained by comparison with the previously published reconstructions using the model-based polar Fourier transform (PFT) method. Orientations were refined using PFT and cross-common lines. Magnification differences between and within micrographs were adjusted by scaling.

emfit was used to model the X-ray structure of the trimeric P3 into an 18-Å resolution cryo-EM reconstruction of the P3-shell. The preliminary model was used to further refine the cryo-EM orientations to higher resolution and was later used to estimate a correction for the amplitude information with ndyn_ctf. This program calculates the ratio of the amplitudes for the rotationally averaged power spectra of the preliminary P3-shell model and each phase-corrected map, and it then applies this weighting function to the corresponding phase-corrected map. The resolution of each reconstruction was estimated by calculating the FSC curve for two independent reconstructions using a threshold of 0.5. The icosahedral reconstruction and CTF correction programs are available and documented at http://www.strubi.ox.ac.uk/strubi/cryo/STRUBI_Virus_Structure.html.

Surface rendering and visualization were carried out with WEB and AVS (Advanced Visual Systems). The contour level was chosen to give the expected volume for the P3 component of the capsid, at 1.33 g/cm3 protein density. At this level, the membrane appeared discontinuous, and so its contacts were studied at a lower threshold.
